      public static Date getCrewChiefEndDayAndHour(Date day, Shift shift)
      WARNING WARNING WARNING : Use calculateCrewChiefShiftEndDayAndHour instead if you are providing the startDayAndHour. This method is only if the "day" parameter is the actual day that pairs with the shift name. The gotcha is with OWL shift where it technically starts the day before!
      Parameters:
      day - The day
      shift - The shift
      Returns:
      The end date

    • getCurrentCrewChiefShiftDay

      public static Date getCurrentCrewChiefShiftDay(Date date)
      A really complex way to say give me "now". This is complex due to Crew Chief's days starting at 23 the previous day. This means if the hour is 23 then actually return tomorrow.

      Wait, there is more complication:

      We take Date as a parameter so we can avoid race condition when using this method plus TimeUtil.calculateCrewChiefShiftType. If the calls to new Date() are independent in each then we can get into trouble if boundaries are crossed. For example: if getCurrentCrewChiefShiftDay uses 23:59 and new Date() uses 00:00. Another example: 22:59 vs 23:00.

      Parameters:
      date - The same "now" as used by other methods to avoid race conditions
      Returns:
      The "Crew Chief Shift Day"

    • isFirstHourOfCrewChiefShift

      public static boolean isFirstHourOfCrewChiefShift(Date now)
      Check if Date represents the first hour of a Crew Chief shift.
      Parameters:
      now - The date
      Returns:
      true if first hour of Crew Chief shift, else false

    • encodeRange

      public static String encodeRange(Date start, Date end, boolean sevenAmAdjusted, DateRange currentRun, DateRange previousRun)
      Smoothness template handles a set of human-friendly labeled ranges, and this method checks if a given start and end Date range matches one of the named ranges. If not, "custom" is returned. This is useful because instead of always showing users some explicit verbose date range, using familiar named ranges is convenient when possible. For example, running a report on "Last Year" is concise.
      Parameters:
      start - The start Date
      end - The end Date
      sevenAmAdjusted - true if a day starts at 7 AM, not midnight.
      currentRun - The current run date range (must be looked up)
      previousRun - The previous run date range (must be looked up)
      Returns:
      The human-friendly range label, or 'custom' if not in the set of smoothness-honored ranges.

    • formatSmartRangeSeparateTime

      public static String formatSmartRangeSeparateTime(Date start, Date end)
      Return a formatted String representation of a date range using "smart human" shortcuts. Specifically, any time with zero minutes and zero hours are don't show hours and minutes (they're implied). If the start and end are in the same month or same year, then the month or year respectively is not shown more than once (it's implied).
      Parameters:
      start - The start Date
      end - The end Date
      Returns:
      The formatted date range
